values.description:
Some example code failed to compile with testing the homebrew bottle:

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder/187/label=osx_mojave/console

~~~
In file included from test.cpp:1:
/usr/local/Cellar/ignition-gazebo1/1.0.1/include/ignition/gazebo1/ignition/gazebo/Entity.hh:58:20:
 error: unknown type name 'uint64_t'
    using Entity = uint64_t;
                   ^
~~~

I've added that include to the test and am rebuilding, but we should add it in any headers that use these integer types.

* https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/616/commits/b65ae4d2844886d37128e105cb47a03f558b8a1b
* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder&build=188)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder/188/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder/188/

UPDATE: that build failed because it was using `EntityID` from old example code. Fixing that led to a successful build:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder&build=189)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder/189/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder/189/

values.description:
A few suggestions, feel free to cherry-pick the ones you agree with:

* Clean up includes
* Don't store `transport::log::Log` as a member variable since it's only used once
* Rename things like `ParsePose` and `poseBatch` to less pose-specific names since other messages will be supported in the future
* Initialize `printedEnd` in declaration
* Use a single `Each` call that gets all entities which have a `Pose` component. This will include models, links, etc. Also don't ask for name and parent since we don't use them.
* Renamed the double pendulum world to `log_pendulum`

values.description:
* This is a quick look at how we could use Google’s benchmark \([https://github.com/google/benchmark](https://github.com/google/benchmark)\) to do some quantitative performance testing.

    I have included some example results here: [https://gist.github.com/mjcarroll/02dffc524d1cd4afc4623fec09b4f953](https://gist.github.com/mjcarroll/02dffc524d1cd4afc4623fec09b4f953)



    In the console output, the columns are:



    1. Benchmark - a composition of the fixture name, the test name, and the arguments. In this case, the arguments are matching entities and nonmatching entities
    2. Time - the average wall clock time for the benchmark to run
    3. CPU - the average cpu time for the benchmark to run
    4. Iterations - The framework will choose to run the benchmark a certain number of times based on it’s execution speed. Faster tests will run more.
    5. Counter columns \(matching/nonmatching\), this is just an experiment to make reporting a little clearer, rather than having to parse it out of the Benchmark name.
    

    JSON results are basically the same, but JSON.
values.title: [Blueprint] Google benchmark evaluation

values.description:
Addresses issue #16.

This creates a symlink from an unversioned library to a versioned library, and they're still installed in a versioned directory.

For example:

~~~
install/ignition-gazebo1/lib/ign-gazebo-1/plugins/libignition-gazebo-altimeter-system.so -> libignition-gazebo1-altimeter-system.so
install/ignition-gazebo1/lib/ign-gazebo-1/plugins/libignition-gazebo1-altimeter-system.so -> libignition-gazebo1-altimeter-system.so.1
install/ignition-gazebo1/lib/ign-gazebo-1/plugins/libignition-gazebo1-altimeter-system.so.1 -> libignition-gazebo1-altimeter-system.so.1.0.1
install/ignition-gazebo1/lib/ign-gazebo-1/plugins/libignition-gazebo1-altimeter-system.so.1.0.1
~~~

The PR also changes all example SDFs to use the unversioned library instead. This will be the recommendation from now on, and we don't expect users to ever want to load a plugin from a version different from Gazebo's but they should be able to...

I also created a cmake function `gz_add_system` to reduce boilerplate across systems.

The most important change in this PR are the following lines. They're doing the right thing, but their complexity makes me suspect there must be a better way of doing this, and there could be something wrong with them:

~~~
  INSTALL(CODE "execute_process( \
    COMMAND ${CMAKE_COMMAND} -E create_symlink \
    ${CMAKE_SHARED_LIBRARY_PREFIX}${system_target}${CMAKE_SHARED_LIBRARY_SUFFIX} \
    ${IGNITION_GAZEBO_PLUGIN_INSTALL_DIR}/${CMAKE_SHARED_LIBRARY_PREFIX}${PROJECT_NAME_NO_VERSION_LOWER}-${system_name}${CMAKE_SHARED_LIBRARY_SUFFIX} \
    )"
  )
~~~
values.title: Unversioned system libraries

Addresses issue #16.

This creates a symlink from an unversioned library to a versioned library, and they're still installed in a versioned directory.

For example:

install/ignition-gazebo1/lib/ign-gazebo-1/plugins/libignition-gazebo-altimeter-system.so -> libignition-gazebo1-altimeter-system.so
install/ignition-gazebo1/lib/ign-gazebo-1/plugins/libignition-gazebo1-altimeter-system.so -> libignition-gazebo1-altimeter-system.so.1

The PR also changes all example SDFs to use the unversioned library instead. This will be the recommendation from now on, and we don't expect users to ever want to load a plugin from a version different from Gazebo's but they should be able to...

I also created a cmake function gz_add_system to reduce boilerplate across systems.

The most important change in this PR are the following lines. They're doing the right thing, but their complexity makes me suspect there must be a better way of doing this, and there could be something wrong with them:

values.description:
This PR adds the ability to specify friction coefficients in `<collision>` elements. Currently, the `<ode><mu>` tag is used since there is no `<dart>` tag or a generic friction parameter. Example:

```
<collision name='collision'>
    <geometry>
      <sphere>
        <radius>0.3</radius>
      </sphere>
    </geometry>
    <surface>
      <friction>
        <ode>
          <mu>0.01</mu>
        </ode>
      </friction>
    </surface>
  </collision>
```

**Note** In DART, the friction coefficient is a property of a link. Therefore, having multiple collision elements with different friction coefficients is ambiguous. In this PR and its corresponding PR in ign-physics, the friction coefficient of the last collision element is used as the coefficient for the link. It's important to note that the default values in sdf are also considered in determining the overall friction coefficient. So, in the following example, the friction coefficient would be 1.0 (the default) even though the last collision element does not explicitly specify that.

```
<collision name='collision1'>
    <geometry>
      <sphere>
        <radius>0.3</radius>
      </sphere>
    </geometry>
    <surface>
      <friction>
        <ode>
          <mu>0.01</mu>
        </ode>
      </friction>
    </surface>
  </collision>
<collision name='collision2'>
    <pose>1 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    <geometry>
      <sphere>
        <radius>0.3</radius>
      </sphere>
    </geometry>
  </collision>
```

This PR provides a temporary workaround for the turning problem for 4-wheel skid-steer vehicles, which is achieved by setting the friction coefficients of the front two wheels to a small value.

## Example

Friction coefficients have been modified in `examples/worlds/diff_drive_skid.sdf`. Here's the before and after behavior of the vehicle for the following command:

```ign topic -t "/model/vehicle_blue/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 5.0} angular: {z: 0.5}"```


![without_friction_coef.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/851060402-without_friction_coef.gif)

![with_friction_coef.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2817758486-with_friction_coef.gif)
**Requires**: ign-physics[ pull request #80](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/80)
values.title: [Acropolis] Handle friction coefficients

summary.raw:
This PR adds the ability to specify friction coefficients in `<collision>` elements. Currently, the `<ode><mu>` tag is used since there is no `<dart>` tag or a generic friction parameter. Example:

```
<collision name='collision'>
    <geometry>
      <sphere>
        <radius>0.3</radius>
      </sphere>
    </geometry>
    <surface>
      <friction>
        <ode>
          <mu>0.01</mu>
        </ode>
      </friction>
    </surface>
  </collision>
```

**Note** In DART, the friction coefficient is a property of a link. Therefore, having multiple collision elements with different friction coefficients is ambiguous. In this PR and its corresponding PR in ign-physics, the friction coefficient of the last collision element is used as the coefficient for the link. It's important to note that the default values in sdf are also considered in determining the overall friction coefficient. So, in the following example, the friction coefficient would be 1.0 (the default) even though the last collision element does not explicitly specify that.

```
<collision name='collision1'>
    <geometry>
      <sphere>
        <radius>0.3</radius>
      </sphere>
    </geometry>
    <surface>
      <friction>
        <ode>
          <mu>0.01</mu>
        </ode>
      </friction>
    </surface>
  </collision>
<collision name='collision2'>
    <pose>1 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    <geometry>
      <sphere>
        <radius>0.3</radius>
      </sphere>
    </geometry>
  </collision>
```

This PR provides a temporary workaround for the turning problem for 4-wheel skid-steer vehicles, which is achieved by setting the friction coefficients of the front two wheels to a small value.

## Example

Friction coefficients have been modified in `examples/worlds/diff_drive_skid.sdf`. Here's the before and after behavior of the vehicle for the following command:

```ign topic -t "/model/vehicle_blue/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 5.0} angular: {z: 0.5}"```


![without_friction_coef.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/851060402-without_friction_coef.gif)

![with_friction_coef.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2817758486-with_friction_coef.gif)
**Requires**: ign-physics[ pull request #80](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/80)
summary.html:
This PR adds the ability to specify friction coefficients in <collision> elements. Currently, the <ode><mu> tag is used since there is no <dart> tag or a generic friction parameter. Example:

<collision name='collision'>
    <geometry>
      <sphere>
        <radius>0.3</radius>
      </sphere>
    </geometry>
    <surface>
      <friction>
        <ode>
          <mu>0.01</mu>
        </ode>
      </friction>
    </surface>
  </collision>

Note In DART, the friction coefficient is a property of a link. Therefore, having multiple collision elements with different friction coefficients is ambiguous. In this PR and its corresponding PR in ign-physics, the friction coefficient of the last collision element is used as the coefficient for the link. It's important to note that the default values in sdf are also considered in determining the overall friction coefficient. So, in the following example, the friction coefficient would be 1.0 (the default) even though the last collision element does not explicitly specify that.

<collision name='collision1'>
    <geometry>
      <sphere>
        <radius>0.3</radius>
      </sphere>
    </geometry>
    <surface>
      <friction>
        <ode>
          <mu>0.01</mu>
        </ode>
      </friction>
    </surface>
  </collision>
<collision name='collision2'>
    <pose>1 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    <geometry>
      <sphere>
        <radius>0.3</radius>
      </sphere>
    </geometry>
  </collision>

This PR provides a temporary workaround for the turning problem for 4-wheel skid-steer vehicles, which is achieved by setting the friction coefficients of the front two wheels to a small value.

Example

Friction coefficients have been modified in examples/worlds/diff_drive_skid.sdf. Here's the before and after behavior of the vehicle for the following command:

ign topic -t "/model/vehicle_blue/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 5.0} angular: {z: 0.5}"

Requires: ign-physics pull request #80

This PR suppresses that error.

values.description:
Component type names were removed on pull request #188 because they were causing esoteric test failures on Homebrew. As that PR evolved however, I believe a few changes were made which fixed that issue, along with others.

So this PR brings the names back and uses them in the debug message when a new component type is used, which is really helpful when debugging `SerializedState` messages (see pull request #184 for reference).

I also expect type names to be used by user-facing features like logging, where the user will be able to specify which components to log via the command line for example.
values.title: [Acropolis] Bring component type names back

values.description: The current `ignition::gazebo::msgs` namespace sometimes makes the compiler confused when `using namespace ignition` and `using namespace gazebo`, because it can't tell if a message is `ignition::gazebo::msgs` or just `ignition::msgs`. Changing the namespace to `ignition::gazebo::private_msgs` makes it clear.

values.description:
Depends on ~~sdformat add\_battery branch \(~~[~~this PR~~](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/513/add-battery-tag-under-link/diff)~~\) for new type sdf::Battery, and~~ ign-common battery\_plugin branch \([this PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/186/battery-additions-for-plugin-port/diff)\) for additions to `common::Battery`.

This PR ports LinearBatteryPlugin from Gazebo classic:

[LinearBatteryPlugin.hh](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/42d7d20dbf5075936965afaef40c8e3d08124b88/plugins/LinearBatteryPlugin.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default)  
[LinearBatteryPlugin.cc](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/42d7d20dbf5075936965afaef40c8e3d08124b88/plugins/LinearBatteryPlugin.cc?at=default)  
[LinearBatteryConsumerPlugin.hh](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/42d7d20dbf5075936965afaef40c8e3d08124b88/plugins/LinearBatteryConsumerPlugin.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default)  
[LinearBatteryConsumerPlugin.cc](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/42d7d20dbf5075936965afaef40c8e3d08124b88/plugins/LinearBatteryConsumerPlugin.cc?at=default)

~~Integration tests are added for single link consuming single battery, multiple links consuming the same battery, single link consuming multiple batteries, multiple links consuming multiple batteries, and links of the same name under different models consuming different batteries.~~

Two batteries are currently considered the same if they ~~their <link><battery name="foo"><voltage>12.0</voltage></battery></link> tags in the SDF~~ have the same name and same initial voltage \(checked by `common::Battery::operator==()` \).

## Testing

```
# Keyboard control
cd ign-gazebo/examples/standalone/keyboard/build
./keyboard ../keyboard.sdf
# Diff drive, left vehicle has battery. Once voltage drops < 0, it stops.
cd ign-gazebo/examples/worlds
ign-gazebo -f linear_battery_demo.sdf -v 4 -r
```

~~This file has t~~w~~o <link>s consuming the same battery.~~ **Update:** This file has a battery `<plugin>` under a `<model>`. Power load is set to 500 to drain quickly for testing effect. `<battery>` tag has been removed entirely from SDF. Battery is specified only in `<plugin>` and nowhere else.

When battery drains, joint forces in the model are set to 0. Currently diff\_drive does not use JointForceCmd, so joint velocities are also set to 0, to make diff\_drive work.

There's some debug printouts right now to see the voltage and number of consumers \( `PowerLoads().size()` \) - these are printed in the plugin and will be removed, but for now, there's no other way of telling how much is left in the battery.

Sample output:

```
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:286] voltage: 0.282894
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:284] PowerLoads().size(): 1
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:286] voltage: 0.231637
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:284] PowerLoads().size(): 1
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:286] voltage: 0.168065
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:284] PowerLoads().size(): 1
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:286] voltage: 0.0787631
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:284] PowerLoads().size(): 1
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:286] voltage: -0.116923
[Wrn] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:289] Model vehicle_blue out of battery.
```

~~At component creation time of component::Battery, whose Data\(\) is a common::BatteryPtr , SdfEntityCreator.cc checks that if two links are to consume the same battery, instead of creating a new common::Battery, it points to the existing common::BatteryPtr in an existing components::Battery. A new Entity and a new Component will still be created, just the common::BatteryPtr is the same, so that it can have multiple consumers and drain accordingly.~~ **Update:** Batteries, including `common::Battery` and `components::BatterySoC` \(state of charge\), are created and updated in `LinearBatteryPlugin.cc`. For simplicity of turning off joints when battery drains completely, only one consumer \(a model\) per battery \(a model plugin\) is currently supported. As a result, this plugin currently also serves as the consumer - consumer needs access to `common::Battery` object to `AddConsumer()` and `SetPowerLoad()`.

~~More SDF files for testing are in test/worlds used for integration tests, for comparing drainage between single and multiple links/batteries.~~

summary.html:
Depends on sdformat add_battery branch (this PR) for new type sdf::Battery, and ign-common battery_plugin branch (this PR) for additions to common::Battery.

This PR ports LinearBatteryPlugin from Gazebo classic:

LinearBatteryPlugin.hh
LinearBatteryPlugin.cc
LinearBatteryConsumerPlugin.hh
LinearBatteryConsumerPlugin.cc

Integration tests are added for single link consuming single battery, multiple links consuming the same battery, single link consuming multiple batteries, multiple links consuming multiple batteries, and links of the same name under different models consuming different batteries.

Two batteries are currently considered the same if they their <link><battery name="foo"><voltage>12.0</voltage></battery></link> tags in the SDF have the same name and same initial voltage (checked by common::Battery::operator==() ).

Testing

# Keyboard control
cd ign-gazebo/examples/standalone/keyboard/build
./keyboard ../keyboard.sdf
# Diff drive, left vehicle has battery. Once voltage drops < 0, it stops.
cd ign-gazebo/examples/worlds
ign-gazebo -f linear_battery_demo.sdf -v 4 -r

This file has two <link>s consuming the same battery. Update: This file has a battery <plugin> under a <model>. Power load is set to 500 to drain quickly for testing effect. <battery> tag has been removed entirely from SDF. Battery is specified only in <plugin> and nowhere else.

When battery drains, joint forces in the model are set to 0. Currently diff_drive does not use JointForceCmd, so joint velocities are also set to 0, to make diff_drive work.

There's some debug printouts right now to see the voltage and number of consumers ( PowerLoads().size() ) - these are printed in the plugin and will be removed, but for now, there's no other way of telling how much is left in the battery.

Sample output:

[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:286] voltage: 0.282894
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:284] PowerLoads().size(): 1
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:286] voltage: 0.231637
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:284] PowerLoads().size(): 1
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:286] voltage: 0.168065
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:284] PowerLoads().size(): 1
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:286] voltage: 0.0787631
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:284] PowerLoads().size(): 1
[Dbg] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:286] voltage: -0.116923
[Wrn] [LinearBatteryPlugin.cc:289] Model vehicle_blue out of battery.

At component creation time of component::Battery, whose Data() is a common::BatteryPtr , SdfEntityCreator.cc checks that if two links are to consume the same battery, instead of creating a new common::Battery, it points to the existing common::BatteryPtr in an existing components::Battery. A new Entity and a new Component will still be created, just the common::BatteryPtr is the same, so that it can have multiple consumers and drain accordingly. Update: Batteries, including common::Battery and components::BatterySoC (state of charge), are created and updated in LinearBatteryPlugin.cc. For simplicity of turning off joints when battery drains completely, only one consumer (a model) per battery (a model plugin) is currently supported. As a result, this plugin currently also serves as the consumer - consumer needs access to common::Battery object to AddConsumer() and SetPowerLoad().

More SDF files for testing are in test/worlds used for integration tests, for comparing drainage between single and multiple links/batteries.

values.description:
@carromj brought up in [another PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/232/acropolis-bring-component-type-names-back/activity#comment-96091920) that we're not enforcing name and ID uniqueness across component types.

While investigating it, I noticed that the couple of tests we have where custm components are registered by plugins (`TestModelSystem` and `TestWorldSystem`), the tests were only passing because 2 different components were being registered with the same name and exact same structure - `IntComponent` and `DoubleComponent` were being registered by the plugin, and by the test. The test would use its own type, the plugin would use its own, and they were stored together by the ECM because they had the same ID. I wondered a bit whether this was a feature or a bug, and came to the conclusion that we should enforce uniqueness and if 2 plugins do want to share a component type, they should against each other so they are really using the same type.

---

On `SimulationRunner_TEST`, there are 2 tests that run in a sequence loading the same plugins, and enforcing uniqueness had some adverse effects depending on the compiler used.

Clang calls the static registration macros again when plugins are loaded in the 2nd test, but gcc doesn't. This causes the test to crash when creating a storage for the component on the 2nd test, but the same doesn't happen for gcc.

I've already put more time into investigating this than I had anticipated. For now, I'm unregistering the plugins in the end of the first test just for clang. If someone else is curious, it would be interesting to pinpoint exactly what's happening; one of my guesses is that clang may be unloading the shared library between tests, while gcc isn't.

values.description:
This PR starts the process of migrating away from environment variables for distributed sim configuration. Command line options can be used instead.

I started down this road because I wanted to simplify the use of docker with distributed simulation. With these changes, and the changes in pull request #237, you should be able to run a docker container in a distributed simulation capacity by:

1. ./run.bash ignition-acropolis --network-role=primary --network-secondaries=1
2. ./run.bash ignition-acropolis --network-role=secondary

The above doesn't work yet because we haven't configured docker networking yet. This PR just allows use to pass in the new command line arguments.

There is also a good case to be made about reducing the use of environment variables in an application. Shell state is a bit opaque.

**Note** The Handshake integration test in `network_handshake` was not actually running distributed simulation. With the changes in the PR, I found that we must destroy the primary server before the secondary servers. Otherwise, the system will hang. @carromj , not sure if you have any ideas about this.

This PR starts the process of migrating away from environment variables for distributed sim configuration. Command line options can be used instead.

I started down this road because I wanted to simplify the use of docker with distributed simulation. With these changes, and the changes in pull request #237, you should be able to run a docker container in a distributed simulation capacity by:

  1. ./run.bash ignition-acropolis --network-role=primary --network-secondaries=1
  2. ./run.bash ignition-acropolis --network-role=secondary

The above doesn't work yet because we haven't configured docker networking yet. This PR just allows use to pass in the new command line arguments.

There is also a good case to be made about reducing the use of environment variables in an application. Shell state is a bit opaque.

Note The Handshake integration test in network_handshake was not actually running distributed simulation. With the changes in the PR, I found that we must destroy the primary server before the secondary servers. Otherwise, the system will hang. @carromj , not sure if you have any ideas about this.

values.description: This PR should fix the segfaults that have been occurring on macOS tests and now even [on Ubuntu tests](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/236/acropolis-enforce-component-type/diff#comment-96647550). The segfaults occur because an iterator is getting invalidated while iterating through `systemsPreupdate`. The solution is to add systems to a queue so that the vector doesn't change while it's being iterated over. The systems are actually added to the runner when `SimulationRunner::Run` is called. Note, however, that the `System::Configure` call still happens immediately from `SimulationRunner::LoadPlugins`.
values.title: Add systems to queue before actually adding them to runner

values.description:
Distributed simulation will make use of levels to tell when performers should be simulated in the same secondary, so this PR turns levels on every time distributed simulation is on.

Simulation still runs if levels are not specified, which is the same case if you set `--levels` but don't define `<level>`s in the SDF, and the user sees a printed error.

---

I'm updating the design document, but the rough mechanism will be:

1. Primary distributes performers across secondaries making sure performers in the same level end up in the same secondary.
2. Secondaries stick with these performers even if they change levels...
3. ... unless a performer enter a level which is being simulated by another secondary. In this case, the primary decides which secondary should stay with that level, and transfers the performer's state accordingly.

---

I also updated the distributed demos to run as fast as possible \(you know... that's the whole point...\), and added standalone examples so that it's easy to compare distributed vs standalone.

Here's roughly the RTF I'm currently getting. I'm running all instances in the same machine though, so it's not the intended use case.

| Example | Distributed | Standalone |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `distributed` | 300~400% | 1100~1200% |
| `distributed_levels` | 300~400% | 600~700% |
values.title: [Acropolis] Distributed implies levels

values.description:
Currently performers that are not handled by a secondary are being set to static and inactive. This means:

* They remain loaded in memory, so if you have 100 performers distributed among 100 secondaries, all secondaries will have all 100 performers in memory.
* They become solid (visible and collidable) obstacles on the way of the non-static performer.

This PR removes the `PerformerActive` component, the `Static` assignment, and removes the performer's model instead.

See the updated tutorial for more info.
values.title: [Acropolis] Remove inactive performers instead of setting static

This PR removes the `PerformerActive` component, the `Static` assignment, and removes the performer's model instead.

See the updated tutorial for more info.
summary.html:
Currently performers that are not handled by a secondary are being set to static and inactive. This means:

  • They remain loaded in memory, so if you have 100 performers distributed among 100 secondaries, all secondaries will have all 100 performers in memory.
  • They become solid (visible and collidable) obstacles on the way of the non-static performer.

This PR removes the PerformerActive component, the Static assignment, and removes the performer's model instead.

See the updated tutorial for more info.

values.description:
This PR adds command line support for logging record `--record [--record-path <path>]` and playback `--playback <path>`.

## Testing

### Record

1\. Normal case. No recorder `<plugin>` specified in SDF, `--record` triggers recording:

`$ ign-gazebo -v 4 -r -f pose_publisher.sdf --record`

This records to default path in `LogRecord`, e.g. `~/.ignition/gazebo/log/<timestamp>`.

`$ ign-gazebo -v 4 -r -f pose_publisher.sdf --record --record-path ./abc`

`$ ign-gazebo -v 4 -r -f pose_publisher.sdf --record-path ./abc`

These record to the custom path specified in `--record-path <path>`. `--record-path` implies `--record`, the latter does not need to be separately specified.

2\. Edge case. Both recorder `<plugin>` and `--record` are specified. Only one recorder will be started, using the `<path>` specified in SDF \(or default if none specified\):

`$ ign-gazebo -v 4 -r -f log_record_shapes.sdf --record`

Currently, it is enforced that only one recording instance is allowed to start during a Gazebo run.

3\. Edge case. Specifying record and playback at the same time is ~~allowed, the playback will be recorded~~ not allowed, because currently the LogRecord plugin does not have access to the SDF being played back, it simply records an empty scene from `log_playback.sdf` in the first case and empty scene from default SDF in `Server.cc` in the second case. `--record` is ignored. An warning is printed. Playback is executed.

`$ ign-gazebo -v 4 -r -f log_playback.sdf --record`

`$ ign-gazebo -v 4 -r --playback /tmp/log --record`

### Playback

1\. Normal case. No SDF file specified, `--playback <path>` triggers playback:

`$ ign-gazebo -r -v 4 --playback <path>`

Only small caveat is that, in the case that the recorded file uses ogre2, the playback appears brighter, because the default SDF in Server.cc uses ogre.

2\. Edge case. Both `-f file` and `--playback <path>` specified. An error is printed. This is not allowed,, because the `-f` file could be a very different world from the one that was recorded from. Since the SDF is already recorded anyway, the user should not need to specify another SDF.

`$ ign-gazebo -r -v 4 -f lights.sdf --playback /tmp/log/`
values.title: [Acropolis] Logging command line support

Testing

Record
